#Text=Belgrade
#Text=Belgrade ( Serbian : Београд , Beograd ) — meaning ' White City ' — is the capital of the Republic of Serbia .
#Text=With a population of over 1.7 million people , Belgrade has been re-emerging as a tourist destination in the past years .
#Text=Often called the party capital of Southeastern Europe , Belgrade is famous for offering numerous entertainment venues , many historical sites , great local food , and warm people .
#Text=Various styles of architecture are found in the city , and its recent resurgence as the leading hub in Southeastern Europe makes it a must-see destination .
#Text=History
#Text=Belgrade is the country 's largest city .
#Text=It lies on the confluence of the Sava and Danube rivers .
#Text=The city has a long history , dating back to the 4th century BC , when the area was settled by Celtic tribes .
#Text=Later , it became the Roman city of Singidunum , and relics of that era can still be seen in the city , particularly at the Belgrade Fortress .
#Text=During the Middle Ages the town became a Serbian stronghold until the Ottoman invasion .
#Text=The city changed hands between the Ottoman and the Austrian empires several times until 1878 , when Serbia gained its independence and Belgrade became the capital of the new country .

#Text=After the First World War , Belgrade became the seat of the Kingdom of Serbs , Croats and Slovenes ( in 1929 , the country changed its name to Kingdom of Yugoslavia ) until its collapse in 1943 .
#Text=Due to its strategic location , the city has endured more than 115 wars and has been destroyed more than 40 times .
#Text=This often violent history and outside influence has colored much of Belgrade 's evolution , which is evident in its culture and architecture .

#Text=Often caught between the hammer and anvil of clashing empires , the city has taken on a unique character , reminiscent of both Austrian and Turkish influences , with a unique set of Communist elements thrown in as Yugoslavia was expelled from the Eastern Bloc in 1948 but followed its own brand of communism until Marshal Tito died in 1980 .

#Text=The city has its own spirit , and in it can be found some not only unique features , but also a healthy joie de vivre in its café culture , nightlife and often a Mediterranean touch in its daily life .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Belgrade has a temperate continental climate , with hot , humid summers and cold winters with occasional periods of snowfall .

#Text=Belgrade experiences all four seasons to their maximums , and those visiting are advised to dress appropriately , and keep an eye on the weather forecast , as the city often experiences sudden gusts of the strong Košava wind , storms , and rainfall , particularly during the summer months .
#Text=People

#Text=Whilst there is n't much ethnic or cultural diversity in Belgrade compared to other European cities , there are minority communities ( largely Roma and Chinese ) , as well as people from other former Yugoslav republics , such as Bosnia , Croatia and Macedonia .
#Text=There is also a small expat community .

#Text=Cultural events from around the world , however , are starting to become increasingly common , particularly in the spring and summer months , sponsored by local arts and culture organizations , and by foreign embassies and cultural centers .
#Text=These attract a good deal of local attention , and help in raising the city 's profile as a cultural hotspot .
#Text=Belgradians , like most Serbs , are friendly and hospitable people , who will always go out of their way to make guests feel welcome .
#Text=Whatever the ethnicity , any tourist who comes to Belgrade and treats the locals kindly will see that kindness returned doubled .
#Text=Most young people speak English well , and usually another foreign language such as German , Russian , or French .
#Text=As with any destination , it could prove useful to learn some of the local phrases .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The main entry route into Belgrade and Serbia is Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport ( BEG ) ( 18 km west of city center ) .

#Text=It 's the hub for Air Serbia and has flights to most European capitals , but especially to Balkan cities such as Ljubljana , Podgorica , Sarajevo , Skopje , Sofia , Thessaloniki , Tirana , Tivat and Zagreb .
#Text=Near-east destinations include Abu Dhabi , Baku , Beirut , Doha , Dubai , Istanbul and Tel Aviv .
#Text=There 's a direct flight to New York JFK .
#Text=Serbia 's not a big country so there are no domestic flights .
#Text=For practical purposes there 's only a single terminal .
#Text=Arriving , you pass through the airside lounge before passport control and baggage reclaim .
#Text=Currency exchange kiosks here give rates within 5 % of official rate , good value anywhere .
#Text=Departing , passport control comes straight after check-in then you enter the airside lounge .
#Text=There 's retail and eating but little general seating .
#Text=Each departure gate has its own security screen and cramped waiting area without toilets , a thoroughly awkward design .
#Text=Transport to & from the city :
#Text=Bus 72 runs every 30 mins to Zeleni Venac , close to the inter-city bus station and Republic Square .
#Text=The fare is RSD150 , pay the driver ( and get some small notes at the currency exchange ) .
#Text=It 's a 40-50 min ride into town , zigzagging through the shopping malls of the western burbs .
#Text=Buses run daily 05:00-23:30.
#Text=The bus runs from outside Departures , so from Arrivals you need to go upstairs .
#Text=At Zeleni Venac the stop for the 72 is the furthest uphill , or most easterly , on the main platform with all the fast food outlets .
#Text=Minibus A1 runs between the airport and Slavija Square , stopping at Fontana ( Novi Beograd ) and the main railway station .
#Text=The buses are comfortable and air-conditioned .
#Text=The fare is RSD300 , pay the driver and state your destination before departure .
#Text=The trip takes 30 minutes .
#Text=This bus also runs at night , with a short break from around 02:00-04:00.
#Text=If you prefer to take a taxi , read the precautions described below .
#Text=The fare from the airport is fixed - most taxi companies have a price list in multiple languages .
#Text=The price is around RSD1800 to the center and New Belgrade and RSD2000 to the suburbs , and includes luggage .
#Text=You can order a taxi by phone or simply go upstairs to Departures and catch one of the taxis dropping off passengers .
#Text=By bus
#Text=This is the best overland option from western Europe while the railway is being dug up .
#Text=There are buses at least daily to Budapest ( 6-7 hours ) , Sarajevo ( 7 hours ) , Sofia ( 11 hours ) and Thessaloniki ( 10 hours via Niš and Skopje ) .

#Text=Buses connect Belgrade to all the main cities of Serbia : some speed along the motorway , others wend and wind through small towns en route , so check : the next departure might not be the quickest option .
#Text=Quality of coaches is variable .
#Text=They stop every 3 or 4 hours for a rest break - keep a close watch on your belongings at these stops , and on arrival be intensely suspicious of taxi touts and supposed luggage porters .
#Text=( BAS , Београдска аутобуска станица ) is just north of the derelict former railway station on Karađorđeva street .
#Text=Timetables are n't clearly posted , or only in Serbian , so ask inside the terminal building .
#Text=Various cafes and kiosks here .
#Text=There 's a charge of RSD180 to enter the platform area , normally included in the fare and you receive a plastic token or paper stub with a QR code to get through the gate .
#Text=If you bought your ticket online , then it might not be included and you 'd have to buy a platform card in the terminal .
#Text=You might also have to pay the bus driver an extra RSD100 per bag placed in the cargo compartment .
#Text=Local buses do n't use BAS , but the bus stands adjacent south .
#Text=There are no gates or charges to enter this area .

#Text=They make regular runs by minibus or large car between Belgrade and Budapest , Timișoara , Niš , Thessaloniki , Chalkidiki , Zlatibor , Tara , Drvengrad , Szeged via Novi Sad and Subotica , Palić and Prokuplje .
